utterances: More interestingly, he's attempting to ring the other three at a time after they've been blown up.

Only Khan left a video message, and a will and testament.

Mohammed Siddique Khan is the man to whom you're referring.

The older member of the group, and the man who appears to be, within the group, the ringleader.

Someone was willing to go, and all of a sudden when they found out was a Baptist church that just kind of freaked them out and they'd pull right back.
And that story would be repeated, over and over again.
Spencer says some non-Baptists are turned off by the denomination's core values.
But others buy into stereotypes of Baptists as self-righteous, judgmental, and ultra conservative.

Either we've got to do a really great job of saying, hey, Baptists are not these things, and spend unbelievable amounts of resources, and maybe really not do that great of a job, even after doing all that.
Or we can just take that issue away.
And taking that issue away was changing the name.
Like Centerpoint, at least a dozen other churches in New England have dropped the word Baptist from their names, several in the past few months.
And many new start-up churches here, are also leaving out the label.
There are more than 80 sub-groups of the Baptist church, nationwide.
Jim Wideman heads the New England branch of the biggest one - the Southern Baptist Convention - that's based in Tennessee.
He says the name is not an issue in the South, but in New England, Baptists are seen by some as outsiders.

I guess that what were attempting to do is to look at prejudices that people have, and say - if the word Baptist is a barrier to you, then let's get Baptist out of the way because being Baptist is not the key, being Christian is the key.
Wideman claims Baptists are not trying to mask their identity to trick people into checking out their churches, they're just doing some marketing.
Churches that are dropping the label Baptist are still in the minority in New England.
Up the road from Centerpoint, at the more traditional Trinity Baptist Church, Pastor Chuck Phelps says if there is a stigma, just changing the name on a sign is not going to help.
We have to begin with relationship in the community and explain where we are, regardless of the label.
But I don't think it's a bad thing to have a traditionalist model in the community, and have a Baptist sign out front.
And on Trinity sign, the word Baptist is chiseled into the granite.
For NPR News, I'm Shannon Mullen in Concorde, New Hampshire.

At about two in the morning today, Jamie Holecek arrived at the community and senior center in Encinitas, California.
In her car were her neighbor's cat and her own dog.
She fled her home in the town of Del Mar.
I had the sense, Sunday - based on all the smoke and the way the wind was blowing - that it could get funky.
Yesterday, by noon, I packed up all the pet supplies.
I packed up any, you know, a lot of toiletries.
I called my - I was actually watching my friend's four dogs and her cat.
And fortunately, she got back in time and she took her dogs with her and had enough time to pack up what she needed.
And she got out before the police actually came through with the bull horns.
That gave me enough time to go back to my place and grab the last things that I needed.
And unfortunately, all the gas stations were closed.
They had to turn off all the pumps.
Looks like I'm out of gas.
I mean, literally.
And I tried three places and the last place, which is closest to my home up in Del Mar Heights - they put the yellow do-not-cross line directly between the woman who pumped in front of me and me.
And...
This is last night?
This was last night.
And my option was to drive up to Anaheim and try and find a hotel or here was a place that I could stay that was closer, that was not in any fire danger and where they allowed pets.
So I thought, well, let me try this out.
And, you know, a lot of people were here.
I was certainly wasn't full the capacity.
And it's not full service.
Some of the evacuation centers are.
It's not.
But they have, you know, availability for the pets and it's been a great resource for a lot of people.
How many people and other animals, would you say, are there at the shelter in Encinitas?
The last - let's see.
A lot of people left after last night.
Morning, we got a head count on the cats and the dogs.
But we have probably a little over a dozen cats.
They're actually in the building right now.
And last night, there were more dogs than I could count - probably about 50 dogs...
Wow.
...in the facility.
And you could hear the dogs out in the parking lot.
Some of them weren't too happy.
Some of them are barking.
So this is pet central.
San Diego is pet central.
So, no one's going anywhere without their animals.
Well, Jamie Holecek, thanks a lot for talking with us, and stay safe.
It's been an absolute pleasure and I hope this all ends very soon.
That's Jamie Holecek of Del Mar. She's staying now in Encinitas, California.
On this Labor Day weekend, commentator Anne Fadiman considers one of summer's unadulterated genuine non-counterfeit pleasures.
Americans eat more ice cream per capita than the citizens of any other nation.
And I am proud to say that from an early age, I have worked hard to do my part for my country.
A substantial fraction of me is made up of cream, milk, sugar, egg yolks, vanilla extract and coco solids.
Before I was married, I frequently took a pint of Haagen-Dazs chocolate chocolate chip to bed with four layers of paper towels wrapped around the container to prevent digital hypothermia.
The nutrition facts on the side of the carton to find a serving size is a quarter of a pint but that's like calling a serving size of Pringles of single potato chip.
Now, under the watchful eye of a husband so virtuous that he actually prefers low-fat frozen yogurt, I go through the motions of scooping a modest hemisphere of ice cream into a small bowl.
But we both know that during the course of the evening, I will simply shuttle to and from the freezer until the entirety of the pint has been transferred from carton to bowl to me.
Taxi.
Hey, can you take me over to Times Square?
But the real questions are raised over Khan.

And the parliamentary committee report, which is reported to the prime minister, says that, you know, opportunities were missed, but it identifies a problem with resources available to MI-5, the security service to the - and being unable to follow up all the lines of inquiry from all the dozens of people who crop up in these kinds of cases.
Home Secretary John Reid told the House of Commons that British law enforcement had thwarted three subsequent attacks since July 7th.
Did he give any more information than that?
Not today.
I mean, there have been a number of other prosecutions since.
I mean there - if they investigate anything, which leads to a prosecution under our terrorism laws, they will say that they've disrupted a potential attack.
There is no doubt, well, there's allegedly no doubt, you have to see how the cases go through the courts, but there are other prosecutions before July 7 and since July 7.
After - two weeks after July 7th, there was what appeared to be an attempt for a follow-up series of attacks that weren't thwarted.
Any connection between the two?
There's no evidence at all, according to this report.
And I've also picked this up from police, there's no evidence of any link between the two.
But, on the face of it, of course, it was coming two weeks later.
That case, people have been charged over that and that one will appear in the Old Bailey in London, in due course.
John Steele, thanks very much.
Thank you.
John Steele, crime reporter for The Daily Telegraph, with us by phone from his office in London.
